alive: Ask them rhetorically “What’s the worst thing that could happen?”
envious: Think about how the ways their life is better than yours
peaceful: Squint your eyes, look up slightly to your right.
positive: Tell them you're amazed and that you want to hear more.

alive: Tell them to get another drink!
confused: Repeat what they just told you
indifferent: Tell them, ‘Wow, I didn't know that.’
loving: Ask them if they have everything they need.
peaceful: Squint your eyes and nod slowly.
positive: Smile with your eyes while raising your eyebrows

afraid: Tap your fingers on your thigh
alive: Imagine that you know a secret that makes you realize how everything is going to be OK. Think about that secret and nod at them.
envious: Imagine how your life would be easier if you were them
hurt: Look at them like you can see their mouth moving but you don't know what they're saying
loving: Tell them that you are there for them.
peaceful: Ask them if they think there is another way.
positive: What they are saying is empowering you.

afraid: Quick! Smile so they don't notice you're onto them.
alive: Ask them if they want to go to Disneyland with you.
hurt: Look at them with a blank face and slowly shake your head
peaceful: Tell them that you are open for other
positive: Tell them that you just had a great idea.

afraid: Open your mouth to say something then close it.
alive: Tell them “Sure! I'll have another drink!”
hurt: Open your mouth as if you're going to say something
loving: Smile with your eyes and nod.
peaceful: Say: “Huh … I have never thought about it that way.”
positive: Tell them that you see the solution now.

alive: Tell them that no one’s really in charge here so any ideas are on the table.
hurt: Stand up and stare into the void

afraid: You know that their intentions are bad but tell them thank you for being so kind.
envious: Imagine how things could be different
indifferent: Half listen to what they're saying
loving: Look them deep into their eyes.
peaceful: Reflect on what is ok right now
positive: You can help each other out.

happy: Remember the best thing that happened this week
positive: Take a deep breath and nod intensely
strong: Think of all the tasks you checked off your todo list last week

afraid: What's the worst that could happen? Imagine that.
confused: Say the first thing that comes to mind
peaceful: Repeat a calming phrase to yourself

hurt: Consider where you're currently holding pain in your body
indifferent: Tap your fingers together while you count

interested: Ask "How does that make you feel?"

angry: Express dissatisfaction with something they're saying
helpless: Think about all the times you couldn't do enough
indifferent: Count the spots on the wall
interested: Imagine more possibilities for what they're saying
peaceful: Let the conversation wash over you

alive: Say whatever is on your mind!
confused: Consider the opposite of what you're discussing
envious: Talk about what you don't have
helpless: Talk about the things you can't control
sad: Don’t look them in their eyes. If you do you’ll start crying.

happy: Let them know you are happy to be here
helpless: Consider the scale of the world
positive: Imagine the best possible outcome for this conversation

happy: Mention something you appreciate about them
hurt: Imagine their words bouncing against your body

envious: Shake your head and say ‘It’s not right’
open: Imagine you are meeting each other for the first time
peaceful: Notice the seat you're sitting in

confused: Let the talking fade into the background
envious: Wish you had what they have.
sad: Keep your hands in your lap and look at them.

depressed: Question the point of this conversation
envious: Think about killing them if they keep bragging.

judgemental: Tell them that you see right through them
sad: Whisper ‘I don’t know what I need’

happy: Hum a song in your head
indifferent: Play a song in your head
interested: Repeat what they said back with more energy
judgemental: Tell them that anyone could do their job
sad: Remember another conversation you had that filled you up
strong: Stop analyzing and tell them what you really think.

sad: Imagine you are talking to a good friend you are no longer in touch with
strong: Tell them that you see through them and that it’s okay.

angry: Tell them, with your firmest voice, to stop.
depressed: Inhale without any feeling of satisfaction
interested: Tell them, ‘Wow, I didn’t know that.’

angry: Stare them right into their eyes without ever letting your stare drift.
Tell them that their behaviour is unacceptable.
strong: Tell them what you’ve been wanting

indifferent: Ask “how would you like me to respond?”
